heading.title: PART 6 CASE MANAGEMENT AND INTERLOCUTORY MATTERS [ss 56–89]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: PART 6 CASE MANAGEMENT AND INTERLOCUTORY MATTERS [ss 56–89]
[s 56] s 56 Overriding purpose (cf SCR Part 1, rule 3)

p.text: The overriding purpose of this Act and of rules of court, in their application to civil proceedings, is to facilitate the just, quick and cheap resolution of the real issues in the proceedings.
[subs (1) am Act 135 of 2010 s 3 and Sch 6[6.2], effective 1 April 2011 ; Act 1 of 2013 Sch 1 item 1.6[3], [4], effective 28 February 2013]

The court must seek to give effect to the overriding purpose when it exercises any power given to it by this Act or by rules of court and when it interprets any provision of this Act or of any such rule.

A party to civil proceedings is under a duty to assist the court to further the overriding purpose and, to that effect, to participate in the processes of the court and to comply with directions and orders of the court.
[subs (3A) rep Act 1 of 2013 Sch 1 item 1.6[5], effective 28 February 2013]
Each of the following persons must not, by their conduct, cause a party to civil proceedings to be put in breach of a duty identified in subsection (3) :
any solicitor or barrister representing the party in the proceedings,
any person with a relevant interest in the proceedings commenced by the party.
[subs (4) subst Act 135 of 2010 s 5 and Sch 6[6.2], effective 1 April 2011 ; am Act 1 of 2013 Sch 1 item 1.6[3], [6], [7], effective 28 February 2013]
The court may take into account any failure to comply with subsection (3) or (4) in exercising a discretion with respect to costs.
[subs (5) am Act 135 of 2010 s 6 and Sch 6[6.2], effective 1 April 2011 ; Act 1 of 2013 Sch 1 item 1.6[8], effective 28 February 2013]
For the purposes of this section, a person has a relevant interest in civil proceedings if the person:
provides financial assistance or other assistance to any party to the proceedings, and
exercises any direct or indirect control, or any influence, over the conduct of the proceedings or the conduct of a party in respect of the proceedings.
Examples of persons who may have a relevant interest are insurers and persons who fund litigation.
[subs (6) insrt Act 135 of 2010 s 7 and Sch 6[6.2], effective 1 April 2011]
[subs (7) rep Act 1 of 2013 Sch 1 item 1.6[5], effective 28 February 2013]

level.toc-caption: [s 56.5] Overriding purpose in the exercise of powers and discretions

p.text: Legislation cited in [s 56.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 ss 14, s 56(2), s 61(1).
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 2.1.
(NSW) Supreme Court Act 1970 SCR Pt 26 r 1, SCA s 76A.

heading.title: Overriding purpose in the exercise of powers and discretions

p.text: The statement of overriding purpose declares that the fundamental judicial obligation to determine justly the real disputed issues in proceedings and to facilitate that determination is being made with appropriate expedition but without unnecessary cost. This statement of the combined purpose of “just, quick and cheap” resolution of the “real issues” in proceedings is repeated in other provisions that confer explicit power to give directions for the conduct of proceedings: CPA s 61(1) and UCPR r 2.1 . It reflects similar general criteria that were found in earlier legislation and rules — such as SCA s 76A and SCR Pt 26 r 1 .

The overriding purpose declaration necessarily implies the court’s obligation that is expressly stated in CPA s 56(2) . That obligation may itself be regarded as inherent in the principled discharge of the judicial function, and a complement to the incidental jurisdiction/power of the courts to ensure the effectiveness of their own proceedings.

The purposive declaration of overriding purpose emphasises the implicit generality that particular exigencies may require measures appropriate to the circumstances in the proceedings. That generality is consistent with the frequently stated reminder that procedural rules are the servants, not the masters, of justice: Harding v Bourke (2000) 48 NSWLR 598; [2000] NSWCA 60; BC200001287 at [26] per Mason P. That reminder, and the generality that underlies it, permit courts both to dispense with the formal rule requirements, and to impose requirements different from the rules, where they are satisfied such a course is appropriate to the circumstances of the particular case. It is complemented by specific provisions of the CPA: ss 14 (power to dispense with compliance with the rules), 61(1) , 62 (power to give directions for the speedy determination of the real issues); and by provisions of the UCPR r 1.12 (power to extend or abridge times provided by orders, judgments and rules), UCPR r 2.1 (power to give directions convenient to the just quick and cheap disposal of proceedings).
Legislation cited in [s 56.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.

The statement of overriding purpose expresses an obligation and confers a discretion. The obligation explicitly stated in CPA s 56(2) is to facilitate the simultaneous pursuit of three objectives: the expeditious (“quick”), least expensive (“cheap”) and proper (“just”) resolution of the proceedings. That general obligation is emphasised by the case management requirement imposed by CPA s 57 , the “dictates of justice” requirement in CPA s 58 , the explicit statutory objectives of avoiding delay and minimising the cost of proceedings (in CPA ss 59 , 60 ), and the detailed directions powers in CPA ss 61(1)–(2) and 62(1)–(3) .

As a matter of practical reality, the overall intention of these provisions was to permit courts to strive to exercise their powers so as to tend to reduce delay and costs (both public and private) in the conduct of proceedings. The actual process courts are required to undertake in pursuing the objectives of the overriding purpose is to “have regard to” the objects of case management: see CPA s 58(1) and 58(2)(a) ; and the apparently relevant circumstances: CPA s 58(2)(b) . That “regard” must, by the nature of the considerations set out in CPA ss 56(1) , 57(1)(a) and 58(1) , be fundamentally informed by the imperative of the just determination of the issues in dispute: Hans Pet Constructions Pty Ltd v Cassar [2009] NSWCA 230; BC200906750 at [36]–[47] (delay in filing evidence and applying for adjournment — inadequate regard to CPA s 57(1)(a) — defence wrongly struck out). There is consequential implication that a court’s powers are not to be used for the purpose of punishing procedural default: Hans Pet Constructions Pty Ltd v Cassar, aboveat [46].

Nevertheless, the CPA s 58(2)(a) obligation mandates that regard be had to both the overriding purpose and all of the objects of case management, with a view to the “best” attainment of all of them: see CPA s 57(2) . Those objectives include timeliness, efficiency and the avoidance of unnecessary cost: see Richards v Cornford (No 3) [2010] NSWCA 134; BC201003931 at [42] . There is an inherent element of competition, or at least a requirement of proportionality, between the objects of case management stipulated in CPA s 57(1). Their reconciliation in particular cases involves a discretionary assessment, on which different minds might reasonably come to different conclusions: Bi v Mourad [2010] NSWCA 17; BC201000654 at [47] and [137] . But the obligation to “have regard to” the objects of case management is intended to inform, and to avoid inappropriate licence in, the courts’ practices in the exercise of their procedural powers. It has a particular relevance in determining applications that risk, or are a consequence of, delay in the conduct of proceedings, such as applications for leave to amend, applications for adjournments and applications for extensions of time: Aon Risk Services Australia Ltd v Australian National University (2009) 258 ALR 14; 83 ALJR 951; [2009] HCA 27; BC200906905 at [24], [27], [30], [93] and especially [96] and [97] (amendment and adjournment wrongly granted during trial); Bi v Mourad, above (inadequately explained failure to comply with terms imposed for tardy and substantial amendment — proceedings dismissed for want of prosecution); Richards v Cornford (No 3), above (refusal of extension of time to cross appeal — judgment debtor’s inadequately explained 7 month delay in seeking to contest liability).

level.toc-caption: [s 56.15] Obligations of parties and their representatives

p.text: Legislation cited in [s 56.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 56(3)–(4).

heading.title: Obligations of parties and their representatives

p.text: CPA s 56(3)–(4) emphasise the obligations of both parties and their legal representatives to confine proceedings to issues genuinely in dispute and to co-operate, by complying with the directions and orders of the court, in the “just, quick and cheap” resolution of the proceedings. CPA Pt 2A and s 56(3A) extend those obligations to include taking reasonable steps, before litigation has been commenced, to either resolve, or to at least narrow, disputed issues relating to prospective civil proceedings. Taking reasonable steps may involve providing or exchanging information, engaging in settlement discussions and engaging in formal dispute resolution procedures: see CPA s 18E. If proceedings are commenced, the parties must file dispute resolution statements: see CPA s 18G–I.

The CPA contains explicit potential costs sanctions for both non-compliance with the “pre-litigation” requirements in CPA Pt 2A: see CPA s 18N; and also the “overriding purpose” obligations in CPA s 56: see CPA s 56(5). These potential costs sanctions may be exercised both in the case of general default, such as abuse of process: see eg, Flower & Hart (a firm) v White Industries (Qld) Pty Ltd (1999) 87 FCR 134 at 150; 163 ALR 744 at 758; [1999] FCA 773; BC9903036 (proceedings brought to delay enforcement of a prior claim by the other party — costs sanctions against solicitors), and also in the case of procedural default. The costs sanction may even be exercised against a defaulting party on an indemnity basis: FAI General Insurance Co Ltd v Burns (1996) 9 ANZ Ins Cas 61-384; BC9603600 at 77,220; New Cap Reinsurance Corp Ltd v General Cologne Re Australia Ltd (No 2) [2005] NSWSC 276; BC200501847 (commercial litigation — indemnity costs ordered); Gray v Gray [2005] NSWCA 129; BC200502324 (testamentary trust proceedings — indemnity costs order refused). The costs discretion permissively contemplated in CPA s 56(5) does not exhaust the courts powers to sanction non-compliance with directions. That is made clear by the specific provisions contained in CPA ss 18N(1)(b) and (c), and s 61(3). A party’s default may be a sufficient reason to exercise the power to award costs where the default causes another party to incur unnecessary expenses. But the emphasis on the exercise of the costs power (and, indeed the other applicable powers) must be the attainment of the overriding purpose, and not merely as a sanction for default: see British American Tobacco Australia Services Ltd v Cowell (2002) 7 VR 524 at 588; [2002] VSCA 197; BC200207341 ; Richards v Cornford (No 3) [2010] NSWCA 134; BC201003931 at [106].
Legislation cited in [s 56.17] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 56.

The courts require crown litigants to act in the public interest: Hughes Aircraft Systems International v AirServices Australia (1997) 76 FCR 151 at 196; 146 ALR 1; (1997) ATPR (Digest) ¶46–178; BC9702751 . Crown litigants are those who formally represent the crown and may include both regulatory and trading statutory corporations: Logue v Shoalhaven Shire Council [1979] 1 NSWLR 537 at 558–9 (local council exercising a statutory power of sale) P & C Cantarella Pty Ltd v Egg Marketing Board (NSW) [1973] 2 NSWLR 366 at 383 (Egg Marketing Board imposing conditions on statutory approval); Mahenthirarasa v State Rail Authority of NSW (No 2) [2008] NSWCA 201; BC200807693 at [15]ff (State Rail Authority party to workers compensation proceedings).

The requirement to act in the public interest may require a model litigant to take an active, but candid, role in the proceedings: Mahenthirarasa v State Rail Authority of NSW (No 2) [2008] NSWCA 201; BC200807693 at [15]ff (State Rail Authority — party to workers compensation proceedings — inappropriate merely to file a submitting appearance in appeal proceedings): see however the special position that applies where a crown related litigant has an adjudicative function in relation to the subject matter of the proceedings — discussed at [SCA s 69.15] Submitting appearances.
Legislation cited in [s 56.18] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(CTH) Judiciary Act 1903 s 55ZF.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 56.

Consistent with these general principles, the Commonwealth and all States have adopted model litigant rules that apply to the conduct of proceedings by government ministers, officers, authorities and controlled entities: s 55ZF of the Judiciary Act 1903; see Legal Services Direction 2005: Appendix B “The Commonwealth’s obligation to act as a model litigant”; NSW Attorney General’s Department “Model Litigant Policy” (Sept 2004). A model litigant is required to act with complete propriety, fairly and in accordance with the highest professional standards. This may require more than merely acting honestly and in literal accordance with the law and court rules. The obligations of crown litigants, either generally or under the model litigant provisions, neither disadvantage them in the proper exercise of the courts’ procedural discretions: Badraie v Commonwealth (2005) 195 FLR 119; [2005] NSWSC 1195; BC200510045 at [94], [114] (crown defendant — late service of witness statement); nor preclude them from enforcing costs orders against unsuccessful individual litigants: Wodrow v Commonwealth (2003) 129 FCR 182; [2003] FCA 403; BC200302096 at [38]–[43] (6 year delay in filing bill of costs — presently impecunious defendant). However, a crown litigant, like any other litigant to whom the obligations imposed by CPA s 56 apply may be sanctioned for default: Priest v New South Wales [2007] NSWSC 41; BC200700374 at [34] (Crown resistance to appropriate discovery).

level.toc-caption: [s 56.20] Related provisions of the CPA and Rules

p.text: Legislation cited in [s 56.20] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 14.2, r 42.4, rr 2.1, 2.3.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 ss 61, 62, s 99.

heading.title: Related provisions of the CPA and Rules

p.text: The present rule complements, and is complemented by, many other provisions of the CPA and Rules including:
the directions powers contained in rr 2.1 and 2.3 ;
the power to limit time at trial: CPA ss 61 and 62 ;
the power to order costs against practitioners: CPA s 99 .
Legislation cited in [s 56.25] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(CTH) Social Security (Administration) Act 1999 s 207.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 56(3).

Section 207 of the Social Security (Administration) Act 1999 (Cth), effectively precludes Centrelink from producing documents in answer to a subpoena issued by the court. However, the court has power having regard to CPA s 56(3) to order a party to proceedings to sign an authority addressed to Centrelink and the Social Security Appeals Tribunal authorising them to produce files to the solicitors for the other party: Wray v Wray [2007] NSWSC 164; BC200701272 per Gzell J (order made on application of plaintiff); Merkuloff v Yalisheff [2003] NSWSC 1183; BC200307581 , Young CJ in Eq (order made on application by a defendant); Attard v Hore [2002] QSC 437; BC200208495 , Dutney J (order made on application by a defendant).
For the purpose of furthering the overriding purpose referred to in section 56(1) , proceedings in any court are to be managed having regard to the following objects:
the just determination of the proceedings,
the efficient disposal of the business of the court,
the efficient use of available judicial and administrative resources,
the timely disposal of the proceedings, and all other proceedings in the court, at a cost affordable by the respective parties.

This Act and any rules of court are to be so construed and applied, and the practice and procedure of the courts are to be so regulated, as best to ensure the attainment of the objects referred to in subsection (1).
Legislation cited in [s 57.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 rr 2.1–2.3, r 2.3.

The section complements the statement of overriding purpose in CPA s 56 (specifically the obligation imposed by CPA s 56(2) ). It expands upon the abbreviated purpose of the “just, quick and cheap” resolution of the proceedings and provides somewhat more expansive references to just determination, efficiency, timeliness and affordable cost. In this respect is expresses the desiderata (of avoiding cost and delay in the conduct of proceedings) that are even further outlined in CPA ss 59 , 60 . The section’s most specific contribution is to require regard not only to the just determination of the proceedings but also to more general issues of efficiency in relation to the appropriate use of judicial resources: see especially Aon Risk Services Australia Ltd v Australian National University (2009) 239 CLR 175; 258 ALR 14; [2009] HCA 27; BC200906905 at [24] , [27], [30], [93] and especially [96] and [97].

The general obligation created by this section to manage proceedings is complemented by the explicit directions powers contained in CPA ss 61(1)–(2) and 62(1)–(3) and UCPR rr 2.1–2.3 . UCPR r 2.3 inclusively illustrates a range of procedural directions available to the court. Most of those are the subject of substantive provisions elsewhere in the rules. CPA s 62(1)–(3) illustrates a number of procedural directions directly related to the conduct of hearings.

The obligation to “have regard to” the four objects stated in subparas (a)–(d), and the direction to regulate the practice of the court so as “best to ensure” the attainment of those objects, requires that each of them must be given weight as a fundamental element in the decision making process: Hans Pet Constructions Pty Ltd v Cassar [2009] NSWCA 230; BC200906750 , especially at [38]–[41]. The process involved in attempting to achieve the objects of just determination, timeliness and efficiency must recognise the potential competition between them, and the impressionistic assessments that may be required in particular circumstances. The issues involved in discharging the obligation imposed by CPA s 57 are more generally discussed in:
[s 56.10] Application of the overriding purpose
[s 58.5] Dictates of justice — general principles
[s 58.7] Dictates of justice — efficiency in the conduct of proceedings
[s 58.10] Dictates of justice — application of the general principles.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [s 58] s 58 Court to follow dictates of justice

leg:heading.title: Court to follow dictates of justice

p.text: In deciding:
whether to make any order or direction for the management of proceedings, including:
any order for the amendment of a document, and
any order granting an adjournment or stay of proceedings, and
any other order of a procedural nature, and
any direction under Division 2, and
the terms in which any such order or direction is to be made,
the court must seek to act in accordance with the dictates of justice.
For the purpose of determining what are the dictates of justice in a particular case, the court:
must have regard to the provisions of sections 56 and 57, and
may have regard to the following matters to the extent to which it considers them relevant:
the degree of difficulty or complexity to which the issues in the proceedings give rise,
the degree of expedition with which the respective parties have approached the proceedings, including the degree to which they have been timely in their interlocutory activities,
the degree to which any lack of expedition in approaching the proceedings has arisen from circumstances beyond the control of the respective parties,
the degree to which the respective parties have fulfilled their duties under section 56(3),

the use that any party has made, or could have made, of any opportunity that has been available to the party in the course of the proceedings, whether under rules of court, the practice of the court or any direction of a procedural nature given in the proceedings,
the degree of injustice that would be suffered by the respective parties as a consequence of any order or direction,
such other matters as the court considers relevant in the circumstances of the case.
Legislation cited in [s 58.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.

The courts' obligation to exercise their management powers “in accordance with the dictates of justice” is intended both to emphasise the overriding purpose of facilitating the “just, quick and cheap resolution of the real issues in the proceedings” and to outline the criteria that are fundamental to achieving that purpose. CPA s 58(2)(a) prescribes regard to the “overriding purpose” and the “objects of case management” as the criteria that are mandatorily relevant. CPA s 58(2)(b) outlines the criteria permissibly relevant to the management of proceedings.

The fundamental importance of the overriding purpose is established by the terms of CPA ss 56(1) , 56(2) , 57(1) and s 58(2)(a) . The emphasis, in both the statement of the overriding purpose and in CPA s 57(1)(a) , on the just determination of the proceedings, is consistent with a long line of authority concerning the proper exercise of discretions relating to both amendment (Queensland v JL Holdings Pty Ltd (1997) 189 CLR 146 at 155; 141 ALR 353 at 357–8; BC9700005 ; Clough v Frog (1974) 4 ALR 615 at 618; BC7400058 — unanimously approving Cropper v Smith (1884) 26 Ch D 700 at 710 ; Ainsworth v Burden [2005] NSWCA 174; BC200504199 at [57]–[59] ; Macquarie Bank Ltd v National Mutual Life Assn of Australasia Ltd (1996) 40 NSWLR 543 at 554, 603–604; BC9605357 ) and adjournment: Central Area Health Service v Cooper [2001] NSWCA 329; BC200105631 at [31], [39] explaining Sali v SPC Ltd (1993) 116 ALR 625 at 636; 67 ALJR 841 at 849; BC9303602 .

But CPA s 58(2)(a) also incorporates the mandatory relevance of the issues of efficiency identified in CPA s 57(1)(b) , (c) . It also prescribes the permissible relevance of the respective parties' responsibilities and performance in relation to the expeditious conduct of the proceedings. This incorporation provides a potentially important emphasis, which requires consideration of interests other than those of the parties to the proceedings: Aon Risk Services Australia Ltd v Australian National University (2009) 258 ALR 14; 83 ALJR 951; [2009] HCA 27; BC200906905 at [24] , [27], [30], [93] and especially [96] and [97] (amendment and adjournment during trial).

The combined effect of the various “dictates of justice” criteria does not significantly detract from the general proposition that procedural directions must be directed towards the attainment of the overriding purpose. Consequently, compliance with procedural requirements and directions ought not be rigidly insisted upon if doing so could compromise attainment of the overriding purpose: Jackamarra v Krakouer (1998) 195 CLR 516 at 541; 153 ALR 276; [1998] HCA 27; BC9801285 ; Bomanite Pty Ltd v Slatex Corp Australia Pty Ltd (1991) 32 FCR 379 at 385–7; 104 ALR 165 at 171–3 per Gummow J (service of further evidence). But that general proposition must be applied consistently with CPA s 58 . The obligation to “have regard to” to the dictates of justice criterion requires a nuanced assessment of the particular circumstances of the individual case and the considered application to them of the mandatory criteria: see Aon Risk Services Australia Ltd v Australian National University (2009) 258 ALR 14; 83 ALJR 951; [2009] HCA 27; BC200906905 at [75] and [98]; and Hans Pet Constructions Pty Ltd v Cassar [2009] NSWCA 230; BC200906750 at [41]–[47] .

level.toc-caption: [s 58.7] Dictates of justice — efficiency in the conduct of proceedings

p.text: Legislation cited in [s 58.7] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 57(1)(a), ss 57(1)(b)–(d), 58(2), s 61(2).

heading.title: Dictates of justice — efficiency in the conduct of proceedings

p.text: Proper exercise of the court’s procedural discretion must have regard to not only the interests of the parties to the particular litigation but also the timely and efficient conduct of the totality of the court’s business. They are both mandatory considerations because of the statutory provisions in CPA ss 57(1)(b)–(d) and 58(2) : Aon Risk Services Australia Ltd v Australian National University (2009) 239 CLR 175; 258 ALR 14; [2009] HCA 27; BC200906905 at [24], [27], [30], [93] and especially [96] and [97] (amendment and adjournment wrongly granted during trial). Even as a matter of general principle, and without the emphasis evident in CPA s 57(1)(b)–(c) , efficient judicial administration and avoidance of delay are relevant considerations in the exercise of the court’s powers.

In particular both the dictates of justice between the parties, and these wider considerations, permit a failure to comply with the court’s directions or procedures to justify procedural directions of the kind referred to in CPA s 61(2) . They may also justify the refusal of applications for leave to amend, or applications for adjournment of the proceedings: Sali v SPC Ltd (1993) 116 ALR 625 at 636; 67 ALJR 841 at 849; BC9303602 (late adjournment application refused); Bomanite Pty Ltd v Slatex Corp Australia Pty Ltd (1991) 32 FCR 379 at 383; 104 ALR 165 at 169 per Pincus J; Marriage of Tichy (1991) 104 FLR 442; 15 Fam LR 65 at 67; (1991) FLC 92-259 ; and see also [34.4.3]; GSA Industries Pty Ltd v NT Gas Ltd (1990) 24 NSWLR 710 at 713, 716–17 (failure to comply with directions — adjournment refused); Hobartville Stud Pty Ltd v Union Insurance Co Ltd (1991) 25 NSWLR 358 at 362, 365 (amendment requiring further evidence — refused); Cohen v McWilliam (1995) 38 NSWLR 476 at 478, 490; 128 FLR 263; BC9501910 (successful late application to amend defence).

However, the fundamental requirement remains that the court consider the extent to which the dictates of justice, in the particular circumstances, require that a party should be deprived of a judicial determination of the merits of the claim or defence: Hans Pet Constructions Pty Ltd v Cassar [2009] NSWCA 230; BC200906750 at [36]–[47] (delay in filing evidence and applying for adjournment – inadequate regard to CPA s 57(1)(a) — defence wrongly struck out). That requirement has encouraged a degree of generality of expression, and apparent liberality of result, in some decisions: see Queensland v JL Holdings Pty Ltd (1997) 189 CLR 146; 141 ALR 353; BC9700005 ; Cohen v McWilliam (1995) 38 NSWLR 476; 128 FLR 263; BC9501910 (successful late application for leave to amend a defence); Macquarie Bank Ltd v National Mutual Life Assn of Australasia Ltd (1996) 40 NSWLR 543 at 554, 603–4; BC9605357 (amendment); Bishopsgate Insurance Australia Ltd (in liq) v Deloitte Haskins & Sells [1999] 3 VR 863 at 887–8 (want of prosecution — principal relevance of delay was impact on defendant rather than curial efficiency); Evans v Bartlam [1937] AC 473 at 489; [1937] 2 All ER 646; (1937) 53 TLR 689 ; Byron v Southern Star Group Ltd (1995) 123 FLR 352; 13 ACLC 301 at 311; BC9504214 ; Davies v Pagett (1986) 10 FCR 226; 70 ALR 793 .

In every case the court’s procedural powers and discretions have to be exercised according to the circumstances of the particular case, and with proper regard to the relevant statutory provisions: NSW v Mulcahy [2006] NSWCA 303; BC200608871 at [29] ; Dennis v Australian Broadcasting Corp [2008] NSWCA 37; BC200802105 at [28], [29] (distinguishing Queensland v JL Holdings Pty Ltd (1997) 189 CLR 146; 141 ALR 353; BC9700005 ). There is no inherent right to a favourable determination, only a right to the proper exercise of the discretion: Aon Risk Services Australia Ltd v Australian National University (2009) 239 CLR 175; 258 ALR 14; [2009] HCA 27; BC200906905 at [96], [111] .

The proper exercise of the discretion may, in some situations, require a difficult resolution of apparently competing considerations. The difficulty of both the discretionary task, and the verbal expression of the ultimately determinative considerations, may account for the appearance of significant differences of approach to the exercise of the discretion: eg in the contrast between see Queensland v JL Holdings Pty Ltd (1997) 189 CLR 146; 141 ALR 353; BC9700005 ; and Sali v SPC Ltd (1993) 116 ALR 625 at 636; 67 ALJR 841 at 849; BC9303602 . A detailed discussion of the parameters that properly inform the exercise of the discretion is set out in [s 58.10] and the following notes. The examples set out immediately provide a brief illustration of circumstances the discretion may properly be exercise to reject an application for leave to amend, or for an adjournment, or to vary pre-trial directions:

where an amendment necessitates adjournment of the trial, effectively reverses a prior tactical decision or is inadequately explained: Aon Risk Services Australia Ltd v Australian National University (2009) 239 CLR 175; 258 ALR 14; [2009] HCA 27; BC200906905 at [96] (unexplained delay in seeking to amend to raise an issue previously deliberately not raised); Dennis v Australian Broadcasting Corp [2008] NSWCA 37; BC200802105 at [28] and [29] (defamation proceedings — fifth amendment — repleading matters previously deleted — substantial overlap with existing allegations — leave refused).

where the adjournment is sought late and without adequate justification: Sali v SPC Ltd (1993) 116 ALR 625 at 636; 67 ALJR 841 at 849; BC9303602 ; (unsuccessful late application for an adjournment to obtain legal representation).

where an application to adduce further evidence is made late and without adequate explanation: Bomanite Pty Ltd v Slatex Corp Australia Pty Ltd (1991) 32 FCR 379 at 383–4; 104 ALR 165 at 169–70 per Pincus J, at FCR 387 and at ALR 173 per Gummow J and at FCR 391–3 per French J (refusal of pre-hearing application to adduce further evidence — sustained default after notice of evidentiary difficulty); where an application to adduce further evidence involved a failure to comply with previous directions and would necessitate adjournment of a hearing already in progress: State Pollution Control Commission v Australian Iron & Steel Pty Ltd (No 2) (1992) 29 NSWLR 487 at 493–5; 75 LGERA 327; BC9203134 per Gleeson CJ (refusal of leave to adduce further evidence).

level.toc-caption: [s 58.10] Dictates of justice — application of the general principles

p.text: Legislation cited in [s 58.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 58(2), s 58(2)(b)(vii), ss 61(1)–(2), s 61(3), 62.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 rr 2.1, 2.3.

heading.title: Dictates of justice — application of the general principles

p.text: The matters set out in CPA s 58(2) are not an exclusive list of relevant considerations — as s 58(2)(b)(vii) expressly indicates. Furthermore the general requirement to act “in accordance with the dictates of justice” applies to all procedural orders and discretions. This includes not only general directions of the kinds contemplated by CPA ss 61(1)–(2) and 62 and UCPR rr 2.1 and 2.3 , but also the exercise of the particular powers conferred by CPA s 61(3) to sanction non-compliance with procedural directions.

The breadth of situations to which the “dictates of justice” criteria apply requires the conclusion that their individual significance will inevitably depend on the particular circumstances of each case. For this reason the individual criteria inform, but cannot prescriptively determine, the proper exercise of the various discretions. Moreover the nature of the criteria is such that they can produce apparently marked differences of judicial emphasis in their application to the circumstances of individual cases. Particularly striking illustrations of these differences are provided by the reasons for judgment in: Sali v SPC Ltd (1993) 116 ALR 625 at 630; 67 ALJR 841; BC9303602 (Toohey and Gaudron JJ dissenting) (unsuccessful late application for an adjournment to obtain legal representation); Queensland v JL Holdings Pty Ltd (1997) 189 CLR 146 at 163; 141 ALR 353; BC9700005 per Kirby J (successful timely application for leave to amend); Cohen v McWilliam (1995) 38 NSWLR 476; 128 FLR 263; BC9501910 (successful application at trial for leave to amend a defence). These differences underscore the critical importance of the particular circumstances, and the wording of any relevant statutory power: see Aon Risk Services Australia Ltd v Australian National University (2009) 239 CLR 175; 258 ALR 14; [2009] HCA 27; BC200906905 at [89]–[91] .

However it is both possible and certainly desirable (in order to avoid the criticism of surrendering the discretion to “idiosyncratic personal responses” rather than “consistently applied principles”: Queensland v JL Holdings Pty Ltd, above, at CLR 163 per Kirby J) to formulate general propositions for the principled exercise of the procedural discretions in accordance with the requirements of the present section. These general propositions relate to the following matters, and are discussed in succeeding notes:
“Judicial efficiency and defaulting parties” at [s 58.30] ; and
“Nature and degree of injustice” at [s 58.35] .

The stage of the proceedings, the circumstances prompting the proposed (including default by the parties), and the direct and indirect effects of the order on the respective parties, and on the court, significantly influence the exercise of the discretion. The circumstance that the application is made well before the hearing may suffice to warrant leave to amend: Queensland v JL Holdings Pty Ltd (1997) 189 CLR 146 at 152–3, 155; 141 ALR 353; BC9700005 (amendment 6 months before hearing). Conversely, late and inadequately explained applications will be readily refused where they would necessitate adjournment of a trial or appeal: Aon Risk Services Ltd v Australian National University (2009) 239 CLR 175; 258 ALR 14; [2009] HCA 27; BC200906905 (application for leave to amend statement of claim made on third day of fourth week of trial — leave refused); Sali v SPC Ltd (1993) 116 ALR 625 at 636; 67 ALJR 841 at 849; BC9303602 (refusal of adjournment application made on the day fixed for appeal hearing); or where they have been made after the conclusion of the evidence: Ketteman v Hansel Properties Ltd [1987] 1 AC 189; [1988] 1 All ER 38 (application at close of evidence to plead limitation defence — refused).
Legislation cited in [s 58.20] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 61(3).

Procedural delay may permit refusal of an application (eg, for amendment, adjournment or leave to adduce further evidence). Procedural default may result in orders of the kind contemplated by CPA s 61(3) . The principal consideration in all such cases is neither the applicant’s delay nor its default as such: Cropper v Smith (1884) 26 Ch D 700 at 710; 51 LT 729 (cited with approval in Queensland v JL Holdings Pty Ltd (1997) 189 CLR 146 at 152–3, 155; 141 ALR 353 ; BC9700005 ). Rather the discretion requires an assessment of the materiality of the application or default, the consequences (including any costs burden) of acceding to the application or imposing the particular sanction, the sufficiency of any costs sanction and any actual or reasonably apprehended impact on the efficient use of judicial resources: see further [s 58.7].
Amendments may be refused where:

a party seeks to reintroduce matters that had previously been abandoned: Dennis v Australian Broadcasting Corp [2008] NSWCA 37; BC200802105 at [28] and [29] (defamation proceedings — fifth amendment — substantial overlap with existing allegations).

where the application is delayed and unexplained: Aon Risk Services Australia Ltd v Australian National University (2009) 239 CLR 175; 258 ALR 14; [2009] HCA 27; BC200906905 at [4] , [24], [54] and [64] (application for leave to amend statement of claim made on third day of fourth week of trial — leave refused). Miljus v CSR Ltd [2010] NSWSC 569; BC201003779 (application to rely on breach of statutory duty — proceedings on foot for 6 years — 4th day of hearing —– previous adjourned hearing — experienced legal representatives — necessity for further adjournment — inability to pay costs of further adjournment).

where a party seeks to raise new matters at a retrial: Harvey v John Fairfax Publications Pty Ltd [2005] NSWCA 255; BC200505684 at [81] (defamation — amendment to plead new imputations at retrial — refused).
Conversely substantial amendments may be made even at a late stage of the proceedings. Examples include:
amendment before hearing to rely on matters raised by expert witnesses: Sheiban v Mansour [2005] NSWSC 908; BC200506717 (amendment to statement of claim after joint expert conference);
amendment shortly before the hearing: Clough v Frog (1974) 4 ALR 615 at 618; 48 ALJR 481; BC7400058 (two days before hearing — amendment to add limitation defence);

amendment during the course of a hearing: Makucha v Brian Tucker and Associates Pty Ltd [2005] NSWCA 397; BC200510059 (amendment after commencement of hearing — wrongly refused); Ainsworth v Burden [2005] NSWCA 174; BC200504199 at [57]–[59], [63] (amendment of particulars on second hearing day — wrongly refused); Macquarie Bank Ltd v National Mutual Life Assn of Australasia Ltd (1996) 40 NSWLR 543 at 554, 603–4; BC9605357 (material amendment on third hearing day — wrongly refused); Badraie v Commonwealth (2005) 195 FLR 119; [2005] NSWSC 1195; BC200510045 at [92], [115] (amendment to defence on twentieth hearing day);

amendment after judgment has been reserved: Londish v Gulf Pacific Pty Ltd (1993) 45 FCR 128 at 142; 117 ALR 361 at 375; BC9305019 (amendment prior to judgment — attributable to inadequate discovery by opposing party — wrongly refused);

amendment on appeal: Classic Gourmet Sausages Pty Ltd v Leda Commercial Properties Pty Ltd (2000) 97 FCR 313; 171 ALR 17; [2000] FCA 389; BC200001390 at [81]–[84] (formal amendment to add a party on appeal);
The question of late amendment is further discussed in note [s 64.30].
Legislation cited in [s 58.25] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 62(3), s 91.

Considerations of judicial efficiency, and the desirability of avoiding delay, may justify limiting directions of the kind contemplated by CPA s 62(3) but they are unlikely to permit orders that operate to the material relative disadvantage of a party who has not otherwise relevantly defaulted in their conduct of the proceedings: Queensland v JL Holdings Pty Ltd (1997) 189 CLR 146 at 154; 141 ALR 353; BC9700005 — explaining Sali v SPC Ltd (1993) 116 ALR 625 at 636; 67 ALJR 841 at 849; BC9303602 (refusal of adjournment application made on the day fixed for appeal hearing); Schenck Australia Pty Ltd v Australian Coal Technology Pty Ltd [2006] NSWCA 211; BC200605763 at [34], [43] (failure — attributable to the pressures of list management — to give due consideration to a contested discovery application); Central Area Health Service v Cooper [2001] NSWCA 329; BC200105631 at [31] at [39]–[41] (adjournment application by party confronted with late notice of expansion of issues). This is especially the case if the proposed orders relate to matters that are, in any event, capable of being litigated in further proceedings: Macquarie Bank Ltd v National Mutual Life Assn of Australasia Ltd (1996) 40 NSWLR 543; BC9605357 (late amendment sought to avoid issue estoppel plea in later proceedings): see also CPA s 91 (which relates to the effect of dismissal of proceedings).

Efficient judicial administration, and the desirability of avoiding delay, are matters of mandatory potential relevance to the courts' procedural powers. As such they are not matters of only limited relevance or importance: Aon Risk Services Australia Ltd v Australian National University (2009) 239 CLR 175; 258 ALR 14; [2009] HCA 27; BC200906905 at [111] — qualifying Queensland v JL Holdings Pty Ltd (1997) 189 CLR 146 at 154; 141 ALR 353; BC97000054 at [24] , [54] and [64] (application for leave to amend statement of claim made on third day of fourth week of trial — leave refused). However issues of these kinds are generally unlikely to be determinative where the relevant application or default (i) arises substantially before any final hearing; (ii) is unlikely to have any significant impact on the duration or cost of the hearing; or (iii) the reason for the application, and the circumstances in which it is made, are adequately explained: Aon Risk Services Australia Ltd v Australian National University (2009) 239 CLR 175; 258 ALR 14; [2009] HCA 27; BC200906905 at [102]–[103] ; Queensland v JL Holdings Pty Ltd (1997) 189 CLR 146 at 154; 141 ALR 353 at 357–8; BC9700005 (successful application to amend six months before hearing); Silver v Dome Resources NL [2006] NSWSC 26; BC200600492 (partly successful application to amend defence after close of evidence); Hobartville Stud Pty Ltd v Union Insurance Co Ltd (1991) 25 NSWLR 358 at 362, 365 (refusal of amendment application made after hearing — claim requiring further evidence); A & N Holdings NSW Pty Ltd v Andell Pty Ltd [2006] NSWSC 55; BC200600780 at [30] , [40]–[42] (refusal of strike out application — despite repeated default in compliance with directions to file evidence).
Legislation cited in [s 58.35] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 52(2)(b)(vi), s 56(1).

The basic statement of the “overriding purpose” in CPA s 56(1) establishes the proposition that parties are generally entitled to have a judicial determination on the merits of any fairly arguable claim or defence. Conversely, the contemplation that a court can exercise its procedural powers in a away that limits such an entitlement, recognises the potential for that decision to result in some degree of apparent injustice. Any assessment of the relative “degree of injustice” associated with a proposed order (see CPA s 52(2)(b)(vi) ) permits, and probably requires, consideration of:

the apparent materiality of the particular matter in issue: Ingot Capital Investments Pty Ltd v Macquarie Equity Capital Markets Ltd (No 3) [2005] NSWSC 255; BC200501724 at [82], [100] (refusal of late amendment — not raising a real alternative claim); Director of Pubic Prosecutions v West (2000) 48 NSWLR 647; [2000] NSWCA 103; BC200002228 (delay in service of evidence — dismissal of criminal prosecution overturned on appeal — public interest in criminal prosecution);

the apparent strength of the position of respective parties claims and defences — at least to the extent of an impressionistic assessment that they are reasonably arguable: Jackamarra v Krakouer (1998) 195 CLR 516 at 519, 521, 522, 528–9, 532, 540; 153 ALR 276; [1998] HCA 27; BC9801285 (application for extension of time);

the nature and extent of any contributing default by the affected party: Sali v SPC Ltd (1993) 116 ALR 625 at 630; 67 ALJR 841; BC9303602 (failure to prosecute appeal); Bomanite Pty Ltd v Slatex Corp Australia Pty Ltd (1991) 32 FCR 379 at 385–7; 104 ALR 165 at 171–3 (refusal of pre-hearing application to adduce further evidence — sustained default after notice of evidentiary difficulty);

the sufficiency of any evidence provided to explain any default or delay by the affected party: Aon Risk Services Australia Ltd v Australian National University (2009) 258 ALR 14; 83 ALJR 951; [2009] HCA 27; BC200906905 at [4] , [24] and [64] (inadequately explained application to amend at trial, after settlement with other parties, seeking to depart from an earlier tactical decision);

the likely sufficiency of any costs sanction that may be applied: Szczygiel v Peeku Holdings Pty Ltd [2006] NSWSC 73; BC200600850 at [20], [36], [37], [45], [53] (application to set aside judgment — failure to appear at trial — repeated default in compliance with procedural directions — doubtful claim — possible inadequacy of costs sanction); Micallef v ICI Australia Operations Pty Ltd [2001] NSWCA 274; BC200104963 at [59] (impecunious plaintiff — repeated procedural non-compliance);
the intangible prejudice that may arise from a party being exposed to either

long unresolved allegations involving serious challenges to personal honesty, professional competence or commercial reputation: Bishopsgate Insurance Australia Ltd (in liq) v Deloitte Haskins & Sells [1999] 3 VR 863 at 867 (dismissal of professional negligence claim — seven amendments to claim over); Admar Computers Pty Ltd v Ezy Systems Pty Ltd (FCA, Goldberg J, 3 September 1997, unreported, BC9704064) (refusal of leave to adduce further material evidence — unavoidable prejudice to both parties); or

unanticipated fundamental changes in the nature of the claim, or defence, against them: Ketteman v Hansel Properties Ltd [1987] 1 AC 189; [1988] 1 All ER 38 (application at close of evidence to plead limitation defence — refused); Commonwealth v Verwayen (1990) 170 CLR 394 at 464–465, 482; 95 ALR 321; BC9002931 (application to amend to raise limitation defence — contrary to previous representations).

level.toc-caption: [s 58.40] Dictates of justice — specific procedural applications

p.text: Legislation cited in [s 58.40] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 CPA s 58.

heading.title: Dictates of justice — specific procedural applications

p.text: The general principles derived from CPA s 58 require particular application in a number of instances that are the subject of specific provisions in either the CPA or the UCPR. These matters, which are the subject of the additional notes indicated below, include the following:
Leave to adduce further expert evidence: see [31.18.5] .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [s 59] s 59 Elimination of delay (cf Western Australia Supreme Court Rules, Order 1, rule 4A)

leg:heading.title: Elimination of delay (cf Western Australia Supreme Court Rules, Order 1, rule 4A)

p.text: In any proceedings, the practice and procedure of the court should be implemented with the object of eliminating any lapse of time between the commencement of the proceedings and their final determination beyond that reasonably required for the interlocutory activities necessary for the fair and just determination of the issues in dispute between the parties and the preparation of the case for trial.
Legislation cited in [s 59.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 CPA s 14, s 56, s 59.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 UCPR r 1.12.

The present section expresses an objective that is fundamentally important to the judicial process. It is succinctly expressed in Lord Denning MR’s aphorism that the delay of justice is a denial of justice: Allen v Sir Alfred McAlpine & Sons Ltd [1968] 2 QB 229 at 245; [1968] 1 All ER 543 . In Jackamarra v Krakouer (1998) 195 CLR 516 at 526; 153 ALR 276; [1998] HCA 27; BC9801285 at [29] Hayne and Gummow JJ outlined the various ways in which avoidable delay can detract from the attainment of justice. Although s 59 itself neither confers any additional powers, nor detracts from the general dispensation powers conferred by CPA s 14 (dispensing with the requirements of the rules) and UCPR r 1.12 (extension and abridgement of time), it emphasises the court's powers of case management and their purpose in bringing about the just and speedy determination of proceedings. Under the Western Australian provision from which the section was derived it has been held that the court has an obligation to monitor, and ensure, the efficient use of the public resources in the administration of the judicial systemen: Christmas Island Resort Pty Ltd v Gerladton Building Co Pty Ltd ( No 5) (1997) 18 WAR 334 at 345; 140 FLR 452 at 462; BC9704719 . For this reason the section should be seen as complementing the statement of overriding purpose in CPA s 56 , although it is doubtful whether its general terms add anything of substance that would not otherwise flow from the application of the various criteria embraced in ss 56 to 58 in any event. Having regard to those criteria, and its own internal qualification, the present section is quite consistent with the approach that the courts powers in relation to delay require exercise with due regard both to the inherent desirability of avoiding delay and to recognition of the “the fallible world in which legal disputes arise and in which they must be resolved”: Queensland v JL Holdings Pty Ltd (1997) 189 CLR 146 at 172; 141 ALR 353; [1997] HCA 1; BC9700005 per Kirby J.

level.toc-caption: [s 59.10] Ancillary provisions relating to avoidance of delay

p.text: Legislation cited in [s 59.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 56, s 56(3), s 61, s 91.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 12.7, rr 12.8, 12.9.

heading.title: Ancillary provisions relating to avoidance of delay

p.text: The general obligations imposed by the present section are supplemented both by the specific sanctions contemplated by CPA s 61 and the rule based power to dismiss proceedings for lack of progress. UCPR r 12.7 confers a general power to dismiss proceedings for lack of due despatch. In addition UCPR rr 12.8 and 12.9 permit the court to act on their on motion to dismiss proceedings in certain circumstances. Unresolved Supreme Court proceedings may be dismissed, after due notice to the parties, if neither party has taken any step in the proceedings for five months and there are no pending applications and no listed future date: see UCPR r 12.8 . Unresolved proceedings in the District Court and Local Court may be dismissed after nine months, without prior notice to the parties, and subject only to the limitation that there are no pending applications: UCPR r 12.9 . It should be noted, however, that CPA s 91 specifically provides that dismissal of proceedings generally does not preclude the commencement of new proceedings claiming the same relief. For that reason, and the general considerations discussed in [12.7.5] and [12.7.10] , compliance with the overriding purpose obligation in CPA s 56 would generally make it inappropriate to dismiss proceedings, on the ground of mere delay, unless the court was satisfied the moving party did not intend to prosecute the proceedings to final hearing and do so in a manner that complied with their obligations under CPA s 56(3) .

In any proceedings, the practice and procedure of the court should be implemented with the object of resolving the issues between the parties in such a way that the cost to the parties is proportionate to the importance and complexity of the subject-matter in dispute.
Legislation cited in [s 60.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 4.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 1.6, Sch 1.
This section does not apply to proceedings in the Small Claims Division of the Local Court: see CPA s 4 , UCPR r 1.6 and Sch 1 .
Legislation cited in [s 60.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 ss 61, 62, s 98.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 42.4.

The section, without expressly conferring any additional powers, requires the courts to exercise their various case management and directions powers so as to ensure that costs involved in conducting proceedings are appropriately proportional to the importance and complexity of the matters in dispute. One criterion of proportionality is the amount in issue in the proceedings. Another criterion is the relative importance of the subject matter of the proceedings. This criterion may require consideration of the status of the parties and the nature of the cause of action: Toomey v John Fairfax & Sons Ltd (NSWSC, 22 May 1985, unreported) (defamatory innuendo alleging breach of a barrister's professional obligations). Sometimes these criteria may be assessed as pointing in opposite directions: Kelly Norris (2004) 41 MVR 451; [2004] NSWCA 260; BC200404971 (small costs order made against legal practitioner — leave to appeal refused). Where the proceedings involve simple claims, parties can expect the courts will exercise their powers (eg, those conferred by CPA ss 61 , 62 ) to impose appropriate limits on the scope of both interlocutory and hearing procedures in an endeavour to limit costs within the requirements of proportionality: Sita v Sita [2005] NSWSC 461; BC200503160 per Macready M. Even where those powers are not exercised, the obligation imposed by this rule may be resorted to in connection with the exercise of the costs discretion under CPA s 98 (see [s 98.45] ) and the court's power to specify the maximum amount of recoverable costs (see UCPR r 42.4 ).
Legislation cited in [s 60.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 56, ss 57(1), 58(2).

The requirement of proportionality, having regard to the overriding purpose in CPA s 56 (and the relevant criteria referred to in CPA ss 57(1) and 58(2) ) may justify summary dismissal of proceedings if the court is not satisfied they involve a substantial claim, reasonably proportional to the likely cost, complexity and duration of the proceedings: Schellenburg v British Broadcasting Corporation [2000] EMLR 296 (pursuit of defamation proceedings after disadvantageous settlement against other prospective defendants); Wallis v Valentine [2003] EMLR 175; [2002] EWCA Civ 1034 (modest claim — estimated two week trial — struck out as abuse of process); Jameel v Dow Jones & Co Inc [2005] QB 946 at 67–76; [2005] EWCA Civ 75 (internet publication of defamatory statement — since withdrawn — minimal damage within jurisdiction and no likelihood of injunctive relief — proceedings struck out as abuse of process). Alternatively, a significant disproportion between the judgment amount and the costs of the proceedings may justify depriving an otherwise successful plaintiff of a usual costs order, including an award of indemnity costs that would otherwise flow from an unaccepted offer of compromise: Jones v Sutton (No 2) [2005] NSWCA 203; BC200504148 .
